Title: It's Anthony Ramos' Time to Play the Villain in Marvel's 'Ironheart'
Description:
Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter

The actor has conquered Broadway and blockbuster films, but now he's taking on a new challenge as the Hood/Parker Robbins in the new Marvel series 'Ironheart.'


							By 

	Carly Thomas


Associate Editor


Anthony Ramos is officially entering his villainous era with his role in Marvel's new series, Ironheart.


	Having fallen in love with musical theater in high school, it wasn't until he got a scholarship to attend the American Musical and Dramatic Academy that he decided to take acting ‚Äúto another level‚Äù and get ‚Äúserious‚Äù about it as a career. ‚ÄúOnce I got into school, it's clich√©, but I was like a kid in a candy store,‚Äù the 33-year-old actor tells The Hollywood Reporter. ‚ÄúI was learning new things. I never did ballet before. I had never done a musical theater history class. I had never taken an acting class. It was my first voice lesson.‚Äù  

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	












	
	TV
			



	
		
					'Ironheart' Streams Soon: When and Where to Watch the New Marvel Cinematic Universe TV Series Online		
			














	
	TV
			



	
		
					Lynn Hamilton, Actress on 'Sanford and Son' and 'The Waltons,' Dies at 95		
			









	In just a few years after he graduated, Ramos made his Broadway debut as John Laurens and Philip Hamilton in the Tony-winning musical Hamilton. That same year, he landed his first onscreen role in two episodes of Younger.


	Now, a decade later, Ramos has made a name for himself in Hollywood thanks to his starring roles in Twisters, Transformers: Rise of the Beasts and A Star Is Born and the film adaptations of Hamilton and In the Heights, just to name a few. However, there's one thing he had yet to accomplish prior to this year: a ‚Äúreal villain‚Äù role. But now he can say he conquered that with his role as the Hood/Parker Robbins in Ironheart, opposite Dominique Thorne.


	Below, Ramos opens up about his preparation to play the Hood, his experience doing voice work for the animated films The Bad Guys 2 and Bob the Builder, whether he wants to return to Broadway in the future, working with Ryan Murphy and Kathryn Bigelow on upcoming projects and his perfect day off work.

	











What was your initial reaction when you learned you were going to be joining the Marvel universe?


	The coolest part was being on a Zoom with Ryan Coogler, Chinaka Hodge, Kevin Feige, Zoie [Nagelhout]. Just being on the Zoom with them and talking to me about the project and teaching me the project and telling me, hey, there's this character called the Hood, this is what he does, this is kind of like what we're thinking for him. It was a surreal moment honestly. I was like, ‚ÄúYo, am I really on a call with like Ryan Coogler, one of the greatest directors of all time, like Kevin Feige, he is Marvel, Chinaka is an incredible writer, Zoie is a great producer. Just on this call with some beast in the game. And they were showing me sketches of him from the comics, and they were like, ‚ÄúObviously Parker Robins is in the comics and it's set in New York, but this was set in Chicago. And you're Puerto Rican, so that's different from the guy in the comics, which is fine, we don't care. He's still got the same powers, the hood is the hood, and we just want to explore what it will look like creating this character with you.‚Äù So I was just so excited! 


How did you prepare mentally and physically to take on the villainous role of the Hood/Parker Robbins?


	It is the first real villain [I've played], because we shot this in 2022. I had played kind of a bad guy in this movie called Honest Thief that I did with Liam Neeson and Jack Courtney back in 2018, but I never played like a Parker. Also just being in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and knowing these are his powers: He levitates, he shoots magic bullets, he goes invisible. He does these things and just exploring what we can do with fight choreography, like how we could expand on his character. Again, moving the character from New York to Chicago, there's a massive Puerto Rican community, like making him from Humboldt Park. Just small things like that and really paying attention to what's already there and then seeing where there was a little bit of room to expand ‚Äòcause it is a TV series and we do have a length of episodes to tell the story. 

	











Is there a specific scene as an actor you're most proud of and excited for viewers to see?


	There's one scene that comes to mind and Parker has his own layer, he has his own place where he works, and he's got this scene on his own with the kind of powers that be that gave him the hood, and he's feeling a bit confused and having this back and forth with this invisible person or whoever that gave him the hood that's not there, but he can feel it there. And he's confused by something that's just happened and he thought he had more control than he actually did, and it was a really cool scene to do. Pretty emotional and it was powerful. It was dope. 


Do you hope to do more with this character and even just Marvel overall in the future?


	I would love to expand with his character, knowing that Robert Downey Jr's coming back as Doctor Doom, and we know in the comics that those characters kind of overlap and stuff like that, so seeing if there's any possibility for any overlap with Doctor Doom would be really cool. Everything is real in the Marvel Universe, you never know what what they plan to do and how they plan to do it, but I'd love another shot to just expand on Parker a little bit. 


You also returned to voice Mr. Piranha in The Bad Guys 2, coming out later this year. Can you talk about your experience doing voice work for an animated movie?


	Animation is one of my favorite things to do in this world of acting and shit. It's just so much fun, because you go in there and you see some sketches of what they're thinking about the character looking like or they'll show you the sketch of a scene that's already written out, and they'll show you like a picture of them running out of the bank and then here's a picture of them jumping off of that building and then here's a picture of them hopping in the car and then here's where Mr. Piranha laughs. So you're only seeing pictures and photos, but you don't really know what it's going to come out like until after you put your voice down. And it's me and the director, and sometimes you get to do it with other actors if everybody's available to be there at the same time and you can feed off of each other. We had about one or two sessions for the second movie and you get to be in the room with everybody and everybody's just vibing, everybody's going back and forth and just riffing and shit that's not even on the script we're just coming up with. ‚Ä¶ Sometimes it's so hilarious, like I can't even believe where that just went, that just went so left, and then it makes it in the movie. ‚Ä¶ There's just these endless possibilities with animation, you can really just do anything you want. 

	











You're also voicing the iconic character Bob the Builder in the upcoming animated feature. How excited are you for that project?


	I was super honored and excited that they asked me to do it. I think that with Bob, it's been so many years where we haven't seen a newer version of this guy. I don't think there's ever been a movie about the village, so like I'm like, for the kids growing up, how can we create something that pays homage to the original, but do something that feels fresh where kids who are watching it feel like I'm watching something for the first time. And even want adults who are familiar with it to feel like, wow, this totally feels new, even though Bob the Builder, that IP, has been around for so many years. 


Having had so much success with Broadway as well as screen acting, do you have a preference and would you like to return to the stage in the future?


	I hope to return to the stage. I've been seeing quite a few shows lately, which has been really inspiring, you know, I feel like I always get this jolt of inspiration when I go to Broadway or just go see theater in general, like watching actors get on stage and give it their all for an hour and a half to three hours or however long the show is. There's nothing like it! Having done it and knowing what that feels like and then being able to just enjoy it and appreciate it as an audience member and appreciate it in a different way. And it motivates me to get back on stage, you know, I think there's no harder thing to do as far as in the entertainment business. I mean, I've never done stand-up comedy. I feel like maybe stand-up [would] be No. 1 on that list (Laughs), but a close second gotta be Broadway. Putting a Broadway show together and then doing it every night, eight shows a week, I've not done anything as tough as that still in my career. Ten years since I've been in Hamilton, and still I would say that and maybe one movie I shot in the middle of COVID because of the circumstances and having worn like a 30-pound spacesuit, and the movie never came out (Laughs). 

	











You also have several more projects in the works, including Ryan Murphy's The Beauty, and Kathryn Bigelow's currently untitled project. What has it been like working with these creative masterminds? 


	It was really a blessing to work with Kathryn, and she's one of the greatest directors of all time. She said something super awesome to me that I'll never forget. We finished a take and we were shooting in Iceland. I had just gotten off of an overnight flight, and they're like, ‚ÄúOK, we got to wait to see if you're gonna drive to the other side of the island or if you're gonna fly because we have to see if the weather conditions are good enough for you to fly.‚Äù And if you do fly, you're gonna go straight to set. If we drive, then you gotta shoot the next day. So I was like, ‚ÄúOh shit!‚Äù I wasn't even expecting to go straight to set. I thought I'd shoot the next day, but nonetheless, the weather was good enough. We hop on this little nine-seater plane, go to the other side of Iceland, get off the plane, go straight to set, I change and then boom, we shoot this intense-ass scene. And I was so tired and I was so delirious, but I think the fatigue and delirium helped me in a way. My brother sometimes tells me, ‚ÄúBro, sometimes when you're the most tired, you give me your best takes.‚Äù But Kathryn calls cut, and she's like, ‚ÄúThat was one of the greatest things I've ever seen in my career.‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù I thought she was playing. She was like, ‚ÄòThat was phenomenal. We got it!‚Äù I'll just never forget that look on her face. I didn't even watch playback or anything, but it was just really cool to get props from her like that. 

	











	Ryan's amazing! We just did the upfronts, and Ryan Murphy's mind is so incredible and his imagination just runs like far and wide. I text Ryan after the upfronts ‚Äî they put together a trailer for the show, and we're still shooting it right now, so when you're in it, you have moments where you're like, ‚ÄúYo, I feel like what we're doing is super dope but you don't really know, right?‚Äù ‚Äî and I was like, ‚ÄúRyan, I just wanna let you know I'm grateful for this role because truly this is some of the most fun I've ever had doing anything in my whole career and my life.‚Äù And he was like, ‚ÄúI really love you in this part, and I feel good about this show.‚Äù It's just cool to know he feels that way. He's so involved and it's just nice to be actually working with Ryan. 


If you have a free day off work, what's your perfect day off look like?


	You know what I like to do, honestly, I'll be traveling a lot. When I get days off, especially if I get a string of days, I'll be out. I live in Miami, you know, I'm shooting in New York, but any chance I get, I go back down there. If my friends are like, ‚ÄúYo, let's go to whatever,‚Äù I'm like, ‚ÄúAlright, we out.‚Äù But also on days off, my family is opening a business in New York, a bar in Brooklyn, and so I help them with that. So it's cool to do something that's not acting sometimes too. Lately, we try to read these scripts for either a job that could happen or something that probably isn't realistic, but something that looks interesting. I'm writing a musical right now, too, any free days I get off, I try to work on that. 

	











It's been a decade since your first onscreen role in Younger, and you've accomplished so much since then. What have you learned about yourself during this time?


	There's never been a time that I didn't have a good time, but I especially make it a point to have a good time on set, because we get to play make believe, like this shit is all made up. And we have to put on these costumes and say these lines and do all this shit, and you get paid for it. And genuinely, I feel like going to work life stops when I'm there. Obviously it's still going, but it just feels like we're in another world now. I think when I first started, I was really scared too. I didn't go to film school. ‚Ä¶ But being inexperienced and just going for it, there are some parts that I miss about that too. I feel like I was super fearless back then, but I think that I'm kind of trying to bring some of that back now. ‚Ä¶ Just remember, just because you can say I've been here, you haven't been here. Like it's a new job, it's a new part, it's all new. It doesn't matter how long you've been doing it, every job is different, every day is different, every character is different. So it's like you gotta open yourself up to whatever is going on that day. But the one thing I think I have kept from when I started is that kind of openness. 


If you had to describe what makes Anthony Ramos, Anthony Ramos, what would you say?


	There's nobody on this planet that's like me. There's no one that talks like me, there's no one that walks like me. You can find similarities in different people, but at the end of the day, I'm me. What makes me me too is that because of God and my family, I was taught that whatever you do, you give it your whole heart. Approach it with grace, approach it with gratitude, you know, with humility in your heart, and just do your best to be your best. That's what makes me me, you know, I'm Anthony from Bushwick, from the projects, from 230 Grove Street, and there's only one me.

Title: Brandy & Monica 'The Boy Is Mine' Tour Dates Announced
Description:
The Grammy-winning Hot 100 toppers are hitting the road together for the first time.


													By
												

	Kyle Denis



	Actually, the boy is theirs. Nearly 30 years after they topped the Billboard Hot 100 for 13 weeks with their timeless duet ‚ÄúThe Boy Is Mine,‚Äù Brandy and Monica are teaming up for their first-ever co-headlining tour.


	As announced Tuesday (June 24), Brandy and Monica will launch their co-headlining The Boy Is Mine Tour on Oct. 16 at Heritage Bank Center in Cincinnati. The 24-city trek will visit arenas in major U.S. cities including Las Vegas, Los Angeles and New York before concluding Dec. 7 at the Toyota Center in Houston.

	











	Produced by Black Promoters Collective, The Boy Is Mine Tour will also feature an eye-popping lineup of special guests, including four-time Grammy winner Kelly Rowland, two-time Grammy winner Muni Long, and American Idol season 23 champ Jamal Roberts. Long dropped her fourth studio album, Revenge, last summer (Aug. 30, 2024), and Roberts recently notched a No. 1 debut on Hot Gospel Songs just weeks before tributing Kirk Franklin at the 2025 BET Awards. Earlier this month, Rowland was announced as The Voice UK‚Äòs newest coach.




			Trending on Billboard		







	‚ÄúThis really is a full-circle moment,‚Äù Brandy, who landed at No. 41 on the Billboard staff's 75 Best R&B Singers of All Time list, said in a press release. ‚ÄúMonica and I coming together again isn't just about the music ‚Äî it's about honoring where we came from and how far we've both come. ‚ÄòThe Boy Is Mine' was a defining chapter in R&B, and to share the stage all these years later is bigger than a reunion ‚Äî it's a celebration of growth, sisterhood, and the love our fans have given us from day one.‚Äù

	











	The R&B icons, who reunited on 2012's ‚ÄúIt All Belongs to Me,‚Äù announced their new tour with a cinematic short film helmed by filmmaker and production designer Ethan Tobman, who has worked with the likes of Beyonc√©, Ariana Grande and Taylor Swift. Set in a maximum sound asylum, the tour trailer finds Brandy and Monica using their powerful and ‚Äúforbidden‚Äù harmonies to break free.


	‚ÄúThe love that ‚ÄòThe Boy Is Mine' continues to receive means everything to me,‚Äù Monica said in a press release. ‚ÄúThis tour is a celebration of our history, our impact, and the fans who have grown with us. Brandy and I have been on our own unique journeys, and coming back together in this way is a reminder of the power of respect, strength, and real music. We're giving the people what they've been asking for, and doing it with grace, love, and purpose. God's timing perfectly aligned us.‚Äù


	Last year, Brandy and Monica earned their 13th and fifth Grammy nominations, respectively, thanks to their featured turn on Grande's ‚ÄúThe Boy Is Mine‚Äù remix. Named after their duet, Grande's Eternal Sunshine single reached No. 16 on the Hot 100 and soundtracked a Catwoman-inspired music video featuring cameos from all three ladies, as well as You actor Penn Badgley.


	Tickets for The Boy Is Mine Tour go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. local time via Ticketmaster.com. Presales begin Thursday from 10 a.m. to 11:59 p.m. local time via the code ‚ÄúBPC.‚Äù


	Check out the dates for Brandy and Monica's The Boy Is Mine Tour and watch the trailer below.


	10/16 ‚Äì Cincinnati, OH ‚Äì Heritage Bank Center10/17 ‚Äì Milwaukee, WI ‚Äì Fiserv Forum10/18 ‚Äì Chicago, IL ‚Äì United Center10/19 ‚Äì Indianapolis, IN ‚Äì Gainbridge Fieldhouse10/30 ‚Äì Memphis, TN ‚Äì FedExForum10/31 ‚Äì Atlanta, GA ‚Äì State Farm Arena11/1 ‚Äì Greensboro, NC ‚Äì First Horizon Coliseum11/02 ‚Äì Baltimore, MD ‚Äì CFG Bank Arena11/7 ‚Äì Las Vegas, NV ‚Äì T-Mobile Arena11/8 ‚Äì Oakland, CA ‚Äì Oakland Arena11/9 ‚Äì Los Angeles, CA ‚Äì Kia Forum11/13 ‚Äì Charlotte, NC ‚Äì Spectrum Center11/14 ‚Äì Columbia, SC ‚Äì Colonial Life Arena11/15 ‚Äì Birmingham, AL ‚Äì Legacy Arena at BJCC11/16 ‚Äì St. Louis, MO ‚Äì Enterprise Center11/20 ‚Äì Brooklyn, NY ‚Äì Barclays Center11/21 ‚Äì Newark, NJ ‚Äì Prudential Center11/22 ‚Äì Atlantic City, NJ ‚Äì Jim Whelan Boardwalk Hall11/23 ‚Äì Hampton, VA ‚Äì Hampton Coliseum*11/29 ‚Äì Detroit, MI ‚Äì Little Caesars Arena11/30 ‚Äì Washington, DC ‚Äì Capital One Arena12/5 ‚Äì New Orleans, LA ‚Äì Smoothie King Center12/6 ‚Äì Fort Worth, TX ‚Äì Dickies Arena12/7 ‚Äì Houston, TX ‚Äì Toyota Center*Muni Long Not Appearing

Title: BTS ARMY Documentary Announces Global Theatrical Release
Description:
The project dives into the fan-led movements that helped launch BTS into superstardom.


													By
												

	Jessica Lynch



	A new feature-length documentary spotlighting the historic fandom of global superstars BTS is set to hit theaters worldwide this July. 


	Titled Forever We Are Young, the film centers on ARMY, BTS's devoted global fanbase, and will open in cinemas on Wednesday, July 30 via Trafalgar Releasing. Tickets will be available beginning July 2 at btsarmymovie.com.


	Directed by award-winning filmmakers Grace Lee and Patty Ahn, Forever We Are Young explores the passion, creativity and activism that defines BTS ARMY. From Seoul to Los Angeles, Lewisville to Mexico City, the film follows fans across continents who share one powerful connection: their love for BTS. The project dives into the fan-led movements that helped launch BTS into superstardom and reflects on how ARMY has become a global symbol of unity, inclusion and collective strength.





	
	
		
					Related		
	

















	
	
		
					Lil B & Kevin Durant Reignite Feud After NBA Star's Trade: 'You Was Once a Thing, I'm Still That'		
	



	06/23/2025	









	
	
		
					Explore		
	





		Explore	

















	
		
					BTS		
					


See latest videos, charts and news



See latest videos, charts and news



See latest videos, charts and news

See latest videos, charts and news


	‚ÄúThere is no BTS without ARMY and no ARMY without BTS,‚Äù said co-directors Lee and Ahn in a joint statement. ‚ÄúWe're excited for audiences to go on an emotional journey and meet a fandom that made us laugh, cry, and think.‚Äù

	










			Trending on Billboard		







Forever We Are Young made its world premiere at SXSW 2025 in Austin, Texas, to sold-out audiences and standing ovations, followed by screenings in cities like Copenhagen, Mexico City, and Los Angeles. The film features stories from ReactorCon in Texas, dance cover groups in South Korea, and longtime fans who have organized and mobilized ARMY since BTS's 2013 debut.

	











	Produced by Eurie Chung, Grace Lee, Nora Chute, and Patty Ahn, and executive produced by Oscar winner Morgan Neville (20 Feet From Stardom), Caitrin Rogers, and James Shin, the film blends personal stories with global milestones to illustrate ARMY's profound cultural impact. Oscar Vazquez and Aldo Velasco serve as editors, with original music by Andrew Orkin and cinematography by Jerry Henry.


	BTS, whose name stands for ‚ÄúBangtan Sonyeondan‚Äù (Beyond the Scene), debuted in 2013 and have since become one of the most successful acts in pop history. With six Billboard Hot 100 No. 1 hits and millions of albums sold globally, the group's cultural influence extends well beyond music. ARMY, short for ‚ÄúAdorable Representative M.C. for Youth,‚Äù now boasts over 90 million members worldwide.


	Trafalgar Releasing has a long history of distributing BTS content, including record-breaking concert films and live event broadcasts. ‚ÄúThe global impact of BTS is undeniable,‚Äù said Kymberli Frueh, SVP of Content Acquisitions and Programming at Trafalgar Releasing. ‚ÄúWe are proud to bring this film to big screens across the globe to celebrate the impact of the fans themselves.‚Äù


	Select theaters will feature limited-edition posters and themed concessions for the release.


Forever We Are Young opens worldwide on July 30. For updates and tickets, visit btsarmymovie.com.

Title: 7 Best Moments From Lana Del Rey's Biggest-Ever U.K. Show
Description:
Del Rey's run through the U.K. and Ireland's stadiums kicked off in Cardiff, Wales on June 24.


													By
												

	Laura Molloy



	Since her debut tour in 2011, Lana Del Rey's UK appearances have been sporadic. A mere handful of headline shows, a string of 2020 gigs cancelled, and two consecutive summers of having her set cut off early by major festivals have conjured a feeling that, when it comes to Del Rey and British stages, the stars are never quite able to align.


	So when she announced her first U.K. and Ireland stadium shows last year, it's no wonder that 300,000 tickets promptly sold out. It was assumed, though, that the performances would follow the release of her highly anticipated 10th album Lasso, which has since been renamed The Right Person Will Stay and currently remains a bewilderment.


	Yet rather than frustrating, for the legion of fans descending on Cardiff this week, these twists and turns are part of Del Rey's charm ‚Äì integral to the air of mystery that surrounds her like a cloud of her vape smoke. And, for an artist whose enigmatic presence on the charts has shaped modern pop in her image, she's earned the right to be elusive.


	It's why Cardiff ‚Äì proud host to her first ever U.K. stadium show ‚Äì has stepped up to the occasion. Ahead of her performance, the entire city is bathed in a Honeymoon glow. Loose feathers torn from boas dance in the wind, girls in white dresses and veils adjust each other's flower crowns and the bridge of ‚ÄòRide' leaks from the open doors of every other bar. It's a testament to Del Rey's enduring power and relevance as a songwriter, taking to the stage mere days after her 40th birthday and looking out onto a crowd mostly comprised of soon-to-be school leavers.


	These are the best moments from Del Rey's show at Cardiff Principality Stadium.


	Outside the stadium walls, mundane British life chugs on. Yet within them, Del Rey has concocted another world entirely. A nod to the presumed Southern Gothic influences of her upcoming album, the show takes place in the front yard of a full-sized shotgun house ‚Äì complete with a white picket fence, creaking porch swing and vintage-looking street lamp that, as it turns out, is primed for pole dancing. White roses swirl around a pond before her, and dancers twirl beneath an oak tree embellished with twinkling lights.


	From the moment she steps on stage, Del Rey's gratitude to be back in the U.K. is palpable, as she peers at the 70,000-strong crowd through eyes brimming with tears. As opening song ‚ÄúStars Fell on Alabama‚Äù (no relation to the 1934 jazz standard) draws to a close, she hurries to the side of the stage to kiss her now-husband, alligator tour guide Jeremy Dufrane, before re-emerging and promising the crowd: ‚ÄúThey're good tears.‚Äù There are undoubtedly more than a few of those on the audience side, too.


	An album might not have arrived by its initial May deadline, but the songs are ready, and Cardiff bears witness to the U.K. debut of three, including western-imbued ‚ÄúQuiet In The South.‚Äù The best received, though, is ‚Äú57.5‚Äù, first performed live in April during her headline performance at Stagecoach and already memorised by many in the crowd. Offering anecdotal wisdom from someone now nearly two decades into the game, Del Rey affirms her tenderly woven advice on navigating stardom by the fact that she has ‚Äò57.5 million listeners on Spotify.‚Äò Notably, a headline-grabbing line about Morgan Wallen is replaced with a knowing look into the audience.


	For the die-hard fans (many of whom have camped in the Welsh capital over the past few days to get a glimpse of Del Rey arriving and leaving soundcheck), the singer's catalogue brims with cult classics. Yet it's still ‚ÄúVideo Games‚Äù, the 2011 breakout single that propelled her to stardom, that is perhaps her most widely adored hit. Now, overlooking her largest British audience yet, she seems worlds from the brand new artist mumbling the lyrics into her MacBook camera all those years ago.


	Del Rey has never been predictable, and tonight's theatrics prove there's no danger of her slipping into that territory any time soon. Perhaps the set's most decisive creative decision was that, for fan-favourites ‚ÄúNorman Fucking Rockwell‚Äù and ‚ÄúArcadia,‚Äù the singer wanders off stage, enlisting a projection of herself to step in momentarily. While the real Del Rey, whom many have spent days queuing to see, is presumably still somewhere within the Principality Stadium, her digital double haunts the porch steps and croons from a crooked window ledge. Bizarre, yes, but somehow it works, and the pre-recorded vocals don't dissuade a choir of Welsh voices from singing along.


	As the show approaches its finale, Del Rey tiptoes down the stairs and into the crowd, keen to give Cardiff one final moment to remember. ‚ÄúI'm trying to think of one little thing that I could do that I didn't have planned,‚Äù she says, beckoning a chorus of screamed requests from the barrier. One impassioned plea from a front-row fan later, and she's leading the stadium in an a cappella version of ‚ÄúSalvatore‚Äù from 2014's Honeymoon, the audience as her backing choir.


	Del Rey's admiration of John Denver has been forever immortalised in the lyrics of ‚ÄúThe Grants‚Äù (‚ÄúLike Rocky Mountain High/The way John Denver sings‚Äù). And, tonight, it's his classic ‚ÄúTake Me Home, Country Roads‚Äù she selects to see us out. ‚ÄúWe're gonna end like we started, with a little bit of country flair,‚Äù she says, stretching her world-building magic a little longer into the night.

Title: Fat Joe Lawsuit: Roc Nation Wants Out of Case, Says It Has ‚ÄòNothing to Do With Any of This'
Description:
The Jay-Z-founded entertainment juggernaut says in a new court filing that its role as Fat Joe's management company shouldn't involve it in the bombshell racketeering case.


													By
												

	Rachel Scharf



Roc Nation wants out of an explosive new lawsuit accusing Fat Joe of victimizing his longtime hypeman via a wide-ranging criminal enterprise, saying it's ‚Äúnonsensical‚Äù to suggest the rapper's management company was involved in any of the scandalous behavior alleged in the case.


Jay-Z's entertainment company was among a slew of people and companies named last week in Terrance ‚ÄúT.A.‚Äù Dixon's lawsuit against Fat Joe (Joseph Cartagena). Dixon, Fat Joe's hypeman for over a decade, said he was forced to work without pay while being subjected to psychological manipulation and exposed to sexual misconduct, including the trafficking of underage girls.


	The claims in Dixon's Thursday (June 19) complaint, which Fat Joe has fiercely denied and characterized as extortion, are framed as a racketeering enterprise abetted by Roc Nation and other outside entities. But Roc Nation's attorneys quickly filed a motion to dismiss on Monday (June 23), saying the company ‚Äúhas nothing to do with any of this.‚Äù


	‚ÄúRoc Nation's alleged role in this case ‚Äî according to plaintiff himself ‚Äî is that it became Mr. Cartagena's artist management company in 2017, and in that capacity, earned a commission on revenue Mr. Cartagena generated,‚Äù writes Roc Nation's lawyer Alex Spiro. ‚ÄúYet, according to plaintiff, the fact that Roc Nation had a business relationship with Mr. Cartagena somehow makes Roc Nation part of a RICO [Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act] enterprise, a participant in sex trafficking, and an aider-and-abettor of Mr. Cartagena's alleged conduct. That is nonsensical.‚Äù


	According to Monday's motion, there's not a single factual allegation in the complaint that ties Roc Nation to any of Fat Joe's alleged wrongdoing. Dixon's lawsuit claimed the management company was responsible for his withheld wages, but Spiro says Roc Nation only manages Fat Joe's catalog, publishing rights and intellectual property.


	‚ÄúHow Roc Nation supposedly knew of this deplorable alleged conduct is a mystery,‚Äù writes Spiro. ‚ÄúHe does not assert how Roc Nation's management of Mr. Cartagena's music business gave it insight into how much plaintiff should have been paid, what he was paid, or any venture to deprive him of adequate compensation.‚Äù


	In a statement to Billboard on Monday, Spiro says, ‚ÄúRoc Nation has nothing to do with any of this. Nothing. And we expect this case to be dismissed.‚Äù


	Reached for comment on Monday, Dixon's attorney Tyrone Blackburn tells Billboard he will oppose Roc Nation's motion to be dismissed from the case.


	‚ÄúI am happy to see that Roc Nation was smart enough to distance itself from Fat Joe and his RICO enterprise,‚Äù adds Blackburn. ‚ÄúThe plaintiff has no personal animosity towards Roc Nation or its leadership.‚Äù


	Dixon's case against Fat Joe was actually preceded by the rapper suing Dixon and Blackburn for extortion. Two months ago, Fat Joe filed a lawsuit accusing the former hypeman and his attorney of trying to extract a settlement with ‚Äúwholly fabricated‚Äù and ‚Äúgrotesque‚Äù claims of pedophilia.


	In a statement after Dixon filed his own lawsuit last week, Fat Joe's lawyer, Joe Tacopina, said they'll continue to fight the claims and that ‚Äúlaw enforcement is aware of the extortionate demand at the heart of this scheme.‚Äù

Title: Fans React to Justin Bieber 'Standing on Business' With Paparazzi
Description:
playlist



	Justin Bieber encountered the paparazzi during an outing and got a bit heated during the interaction. The moment quickly went viral on social media and even turned into a meme. We went to the streets to have fans weigh in on the interaction to determine whether Bieber's reaction was valid or not.


	What did you think of the viral interaction? Let us know in the comments!


	Guest 1:


	It is what it is, bro. There're paparazzi everywhere for you. Like, you're Justin Bieber, bro.  


	Tetris Kelly:


	Last week, Justin Bieber stood on business as he confronted a group of paparazzi who was determined to kill his vibe. 


	Guest 2:


	I don't know. It just seems kind of off to me. 


	Tetris Kelly:


	In the video, Justin can be heard saying, ‚ÄúIt's not clocking to you that I'm standing on business. Is it?‚Äù Things got a little heated between Justin and the paps. Their exchange went viral from content creator re-enactments. Justin, having a little fun himself, took to Instagram where he shared a content creator's remix of his viral moment. Then Justin posted a black-and-white image with the caption, ‚Äúy'all think the business is a joke, but you're drunk.‚Äù This video of Justin and the paparazzi has started an interesting discourse online. In the video, Justin talks about setting boundaries while the paparazzi say they're just doing their jobs. But we started to wonder: Who's right? Should Justin be left alone, or were the paparazzi just doing their jobs? We took it to the streets of West Hollywood to see what you all thought. 


	Guest 3:


	He's always reacted a little bit, you know, strange when it comes to paparazzi and stuff. Who knows what's going on through his head. But I feel like you know what you sign up for when you become a celebrity. 


Keep watching for more.

Title: ‚ÄòBet' Renewed For Second Season By Netflix
Description:
By Lynette Rice 

Senior TV Writer


	The Netflix live-action series Bet that's based on the Japanese manga Kakegurui has been renewed for a second season. The new season will feature 10, 30-minute episodes. 


Bet follows the students at a boarding school for the global elite, where underground gambling determines the school's hierarchy. When Yumeko (Miku Martineau), a mysterious transfer student arrives, her gambling prowess puts her in the crosshairs of the powerful Student Council, while her secret quest for revenge threatens to upend the school's status quo entirely.


	The series spent three weeks in the global Top 10 of English-speaking shows following its season one release.

	











	‚ÄúI'm extremely happy for our amazing Bet fans from all over the world, who get to enjoy another season, and for this incredible cast and crew to return to St. Dominic's for more gambling and general madness,‚Äù said Showrunner/Director Simon Barry in a statement. 




			Watch on Deadline		







	The cast also features Ayo Solanke, Eve Edwards, Clara Alexandrova, Hunter Cardinal, Anwen O'Driscoll, Aviva Mongillo, Laura Afelskie, Dorian Giordano, Emma Elle Paterson, Ryan Sutherland, and Peter Outerbridge.


	Executive Producers are Barry, Jeff F. King, David Fortier, Ivan Schneeberg, Jon Rutherford and Nick Nantell. The production company is Boat Rocker.

Title: Cillian Murphy-Led ‚ÄòSteve' Sets Fall Theatrical & Netflix Release; Supporting Cast Includes Tracey Ullman, Simbi Ajikawo, Emily Watson
Description:
By Nancy Tartaglione 

International Box Office Editor/Senior Contributor


	Oscar winner Cillian Murphy's next feature, Steve, will receive a theatrical release in select cinemas in September before dropping on Netflix on October 3. We've got a first-look image of Murphy in the eponymous role ‚Äì scroll down to check it out. 


	Murphy also produces the reform school drama under his Big Things Films banner with partner Alan Moloney, and in collaboration with Netflix which handles global distribution. The release dates could point to fall film festival play.


	Directed by Tim Mielants, Steve is a reimagining of Max Porter's novel Shy, and also stars the previously announced Jay Lycurgo. Supporting cast revealed today are Emmy and Golden Globe winner Tracey Ullman, Top Boy's Simbi Ajikawo (aka Little Simz) and BAFTA winner and Oscar nominee Emily Watson. Mielants recently helmed Netflix's Murphy-starrer Small Things Like These in which Watson featured.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Secret Netflix Movie That Landed Lofty California Tax Credit Is Likely Brad Pitt's 'Adventures Of Cliff Booth' - The Dish		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Darren Star On 'Younger's Streaming Resurgence & Prospects Of Revival		
			








	Set in the mid-1990s, Steve follows a pivotal day in the life of the titular headteacher and his students at a last-chance reform school amidst a world that has forsaken them. As Steve fights to protect the school's integrity and impending closure, he grapples with his own mental health. In parallel to Steve's struggles, troubled teen Shy (Lycurgo) is caught between his past and what lies ahead as he tries to reconcile his inner fragility with his impulse for self-destruction and violence. 




			Watch on Deadline		







	Additional cast members include Douggie McMeekin, Youssef Kerkour, Luke Ayres, Joshua J Parker, Araloyin Oshunremi, Tut Nyuot, Tom Moya, Ahmed Ismail, Joshua Barry, Archie Fisher, Ben Lloyd-Hughes, Priyanga Burford, George Fouracres, Marcus Garvey, Ruby Ashbourne-Serkis and Roger Allam. Tina Pawlik also produces. Porter wrote the screenplay and exec produces. Music is by Ben Salisbury and Geoff Barrow.

Title: Xavier Molyneux Lands Lead Role In Amazon MGM Studios' Viking Series ‚ÄòBloodaxe'
Description:
By Matt Grobar 

Senior Film Reporter


EXCLUSIVE: Relative newcomer Xavier Molyneux has landed the title role in Bloodaxe, Prime Video's new historical drama series from Vikings creator Michael Hirst and his son, Horatio Hirst, sources tell Deadline.


	Reps for Amazon MGM Studios couldn't be reached for comment. 


Officially ordered in March, Bloodaxe chronicles the rise of one of history's most famous Viking warriors, Erik Bloodaxe (Molyneux), and his formidable wife, Gunnhild, Mother of Kings. As they fight for the throne of Norway, the land is torn apart by fierce rivals, shifting loyalties and bloody betrayals. With war looming and chaos consuming the kingdom, drawing in the ruthless kings of other Scandinavian countries and even a powerful English ruler, the stage is set for a thundering new Viking saga.

	











Bloodaxe is created, written and exec produced by Michael and Horatio Hirst and produced by MGM Television. Other exec producers include Steve Stark of Toluca Pictures label who, as head of MGM Television, oversaw both of the 2013-20 Vikings TV series, along with fellow franchise alum Morgan O'Sullivan, Arturo Interian, John Weber and Sheila Hockin.




			Watch on Deadline		







RELATED: 2025 Premiere Dates For New & Returning Series On Broadcast, Cable & Streaming


	While the show shares creative lineage with the 2013-20 History series Vikings and the 2022-25 Netflix follow-up Vikings: Valhalla ‚Äî all three are based on historical figures and produced by MGM Television ‚Äî Bloodaxe is not directly related to those efforts. The new Norse saga takes place decades after the original series and decades before Valhalla. Production begins in Ireland at the end of July.

	











	A rising Australian actor currently based in New Zealand, Molyneux just wrapped his run on the iconic Australian soap Neighbours and also recently starred in Netflix's romantic drama Take My Hand. He is repped by Benchmark Creative Management in Australia and The Rosenzweig Group.

Title: UK Actors Union Says ‚ÄúThousands Of Performers‚Äù Have Been ‚ÄúDigitally Scanned On Set Without Their Informed Consent‚Äù In Open Letter To Pact Signed By Emma D'Arcy, Tamsin Greig, Nicola Walker
Description:
By Max Goldbart 

International TV Co-Editor


EXCLUSIVE: Thousands of UK actors have been ‚Äúdigitally scanned on set without their informed consent,‚Äù according to an open letter from Brit actors union Equity urging progress on artificial intelligence as it returns to the negotiating table with Pact. 


	British actors Emma D'Arcy, Tamsin Greig, Alan Davies, Nicola Walker and Wilf Scolding have so far signed the letter, which was published last week. 


	‚ÄúWe also have no transparency around how our performances, likeness and personal data are being recorded, stored and processed within the context of the production and beyond,‚Äù Equity wrote, in the letter to Pact that has amassed nearly 1,500 signatures. 

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Donald Trump's "One Big Beautiful Bill" Can Retain Provision That Bans States From Regulating AI, Senate Parliamentarian Concludes		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Bruce Lee & Jackie Chan Films Among Kung Fu Classics Set For AI Restorations 		
			








	The letter comes a day before Equity and the producer trade body are due to sit down for yet another round of negotiations on a set of new collective agreements that has been rumbling for around 12 months, with AI safeguards proving quite the sticking point. Equity has been upping the stakes in recent months, with re-elected General Secretary Paul Fleming saying the union is ‚Äúindustrial action ready‚Äù if negotiations keep failing while the union threatened court action to the BBC, ITV, Disney and Pact if members rights are breached in the training of AI models.




			Watch on Deadline		







	‚ÄúWe are writing ahead of your negotiation meeting with Equity Officials on 25 June to express concern at the lack of progress on securing AI protections for performers,‚Äù wrote Equity in the open letter. ‚ÄúWe believe this is unacceptable and urge Pact to prioritise this crucial area affecting our industry and livelihoods.‚Äù Pact declined comment.


	Using the new U.S. SAG-AFTRA contacts as a partial blueprint, Equity's claim with Pact is tailored to the implications of generative AI for different categories of actor including dubbing and supporting artists. Equity said it has put forward ‚Äúa constructive proposal‚Äù including ‚Äúimportant provisions on AI training, which the union has made clear is a red line in these negotiations.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe will not accept any deal that does not grant us key protections for the use of our personal data for training AI systems and creating AI-generated performances,‚Äù it added today.

	











	The collective agreements being negotiated govern the vast majority of British TV shows and indie movies. Adding to the confusion, the BBC and ITV's separate agreements with Equity failed to include artificial intelligence safeguards as the broadcasters did not want to include them until the Equity-Pact negotiations are resolved. The broadcasters have insisted that ‚Äúdiscussion around AI provisions remains firmly on the table.‚Äù


	The move comes as the UK government considers legislation that would mean copyright holders must opt-out from having their material used for training generative AI models. A BFI report earlier this month revealed that scripts from more than 130,000 films and TV shows have been used to train such models.

Title: Hayley Kiyoko's ‚ÄòGirls Like Girls' Sets Maya da Costa & Myra Molloy At Focus Features
Description:
By Anthony D'Alessandro 

Editorial Director/Box Office Editor


	 Multi-hyphenate Hayley Kiyoko unveiled on Instagram today that her directorial debut Girls Like Girls at Focus Features will star Maya da Costa (Under The Bridge) and Myra Molloy (He's All That). 


	The movie is based on Kiyoko's hit song and viral music video of the same name. da Costa will play Coley while Myra will portray Sonya. The feature ‚Äútells the universal story of falling in love for the first time and learning to accept yourself along the way‚Äù per the press release this AM. 


	Today's announcement coincides with the 10th anniversary of the Girls Like Girls music video which dropped on June 24, 2015 and garnered north of 145M views. In 2023, Kiyoko released the New York Times Best Selling novel Girls Like Girls, which expanded upon the characters from her music video. In 2019, Billboard included the ditty in its list of the ‚Äú30 Lesbian Love Songs‚Äù. 

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	Trailers
	



	
		
					'Downton Abbey: The Grand Finale' Teaser Trailer Sees Grantham Estate Get A Kiss Goodbye		
			















	News
	



	
		
					'The Phoenician Scheme' Lands Top Limited Opening Of 2025 - Specialty Box Office		
			








	The music video follows Coley and Sonya as they learn about their for each other. However, Sonya's boyfriend is greatly in the way, and actually assaults Coley after he finds the two women kissing. Coley punches back, and Sonya manages to hear her off of him. The video ends with Coley and Sonya in bliss. 




			Watch on Deadline		







	Kiyoko co-wrote the screenplay with Stefanie Scott, the actress who starred as Coley in the original music video. 


	Marc Platt, Katie McNicol, Adam Siegel, and Dee Best are producing for Marc Platt Productions, Michael Philip and Jason Moring are producing alongside BuzzFeed Studios' Richard Alan Reid.

	











	Kiyoko is represented by ATC, Kaplan-Perrone, Cultured Artists and CAA. da Costa is represented by da Costa Talent and Jackoway Austen Tyerman. Molloy is represented by Gersh and Luber Roklin Entertainment.

Title: Trump Rages At Ongoing Israel-Iran Hostilities Live On TV: ‚ÄúThey Don't Know What The F*ck They're Doing‚Äù
Description:
By Jake Kanter, Ted Johnson 


Donald Trump did little to hide his anger at continued hostilities between Israel and Iran on Tuesday, censuring the nations in expletive-embellished remarks at the White House.


	Speaking as he was about to board Marine One for a NATO summit in the Netherlands, Trump told reporters, ‚ÄúWe basically have two countries that have been fighting so long and so hard that they don't know what the f*ck they're doing.‚Äù


	The outburst followed Israel saying it had intercepted a missile launched by Iran, soon after Trump had hailed an ‚Äúepic ceasefire‚Äù between the two countries. Israel accused Iran of violating the terms of the ceasefire and vowed to launch fresh strikes. Iran denied the allegations.

	










President Trump on Israel and Iran: "We basically have two countries that have been fighting so long and so hard that they don't know what the fuck they're doing." pic.twitter.com/xrztmebALZ


	Trump accused Israel of targeting Tehran soon after a deal was struck, saying both sides violated the peace agreement.




			Watch on Deadline		







	‚ÄúIsrael, as soon as we made the deal, they came out and they dropped a load of bombs, the likes of which I've never seen before, the biggest load that we've seen. I'm not happy with Israel,‚Äù Trump told reporters.


	‚ÄúYou don't go out in the first hour and just drop everything you have on them. So I'm not happy with them. I'm not happy with Iran either.‚Äù


	After making his TV comments about the perilous situation in the Middle East, the president appeared to continue his interventions from Marine One, posting several times on Truth Social. He warned Israel not to attack Iran.


	‚ÄúISRAEL. DO NOT DROP THOSE BOMBS. IF YOU DO IT IS A MAJOR VIOLATION. BRING YOUR PILOTS HOME, NOW!‚Äù he wrote. Trump later added: ‚ÄúISRAEL is not going to attack Iran. All planes will turn around and head home, while doing a friendly ‚ÄòPlane Wave' to Iran. Nobody will be hurt, the Ceasefire is in effect!‚Äù

	











	Sky News, the UK broadcaster, carried Trump's comments live and apologized for the president's language. 

‚ÄúWe're just going to apologise for the language by the US President, there.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/IiDCbYat6c


	In his remarks to reporters before leaving on his trip, Trump also lashed out again at news outlets that have reported some skepticism about the U.S. bombings and whether they neutralized Iran's nuclear capabilities. 


	‚ÄúIf you take a look at the pinprick, then you see that place is gone,‚Äù Trump said of destruction assessments. ‚ÄúAnd I say, I think CNN ought to apologize to the pilots of the B-2s. I think that MSDNC ought to apologize. I think that these guys, and these cable networks, are real losers. You really are.‚Äù


	‚ÄúThey're gutless losers. I say that to CNN because I watch it, I have no choice. I've got to watch this garbage. It's all garbage, it's all fake news. But I think CNN is  a gutless group of people. And the people that run it, no one even knows this because it's been sold so many times, but the people that run it ought to be ashamed.‚Äù


	‚ÄúMSDNC, a guy named Brian Roberts, he heads it, he's a disgrace. He's a weak, pathetic disgrace.‚Äù Roberts is the CEO of MSNBC parent Comcast.

Title: Diego Luna rebukes Trump's immigration policies in first Jimmy Kimmel guest host monologue
Description:
Diego Luna let the president know exactly how he felt about his draconian immigration policy when he took over as a guest host on Jimmy Kimmel Live! Monday night. ‚ÄúTonight, I want to address an important issue that is happening here in Los Angeles and all around the United States,‚Äù the Andor actor said in his opening monologue. ‚ÄúWith everything going on in this country around immigration and authoritarian policies of Donald Trump, it is no small thing that a Mexican is hosting such an important show. It's a big deal and I really hope not to fuck it up.‚Äù

The actor then took some time to reflect on his own experience in Los Angeles, sharing that he first ‚Äústepped foot in the territory known as the United States‚Äù at 20 years old following the success of Y Tu Mam√° Tambi√©n. He now even has an Angeleno son, he shared. But, he continued, ‚Äúthe people that lifted me up were mostly people that had left their countries to find a new life, or the sons and daughters of immigrants that had come here in order to work and build a healthy, enjoyable and dignified life, away from their place of origin.‚Äù

‚ÄúA movement of that scale, that's not natural, not unless something is very, very wrong in the place you are coming from,‚Äù Luna continued. ‚ÄúNobody leaves their land if it's not because their survival depends on it. Nobody leaves their past behind, just for fun. But you know what? All the people that I met shared an unspoken gratitude to this country, a country that opened its doors to them.‚Äù

Los Angeles, he continued, is ‚Äúa powerful example of what's possible, of what can be achieved when we put empathy first.‚Äù The city has also become a lightning rod in the fight over Trump's immigration policy, as the president moved to deploy the National Guard to step in as ICE clashed with protesters earlier this month. California Governor Gavin Newsom is now sparring with Trump over this decision in court.

Luna then took a moment to laud the fact that ‚Äúthe multiple times that this country has had to rebuild itself, immigrants were always there to pick up the slack.‚Äù He specifically reminded audiences of the L.A. wildfires earlier this year, which saw ‚Äúimmigrant workers risk their lives to stop the flames.‚Äù He continued, ‚ÄúThey are the ones who build this country, they feed it, they nurture and teach its children, they care for the elderly, they work in construction, hospitality, they run kitchens. They're technicians, merchants, athletes, drivers, farmers.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere are a lot of lies flying around about immigrants, but I'm sure you have more than one story that can attest to the contrary. Talk about it, share it. That helps. Today, they need to know that they're not alone,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThese have been a dark few weeks. It is not acceptable nor is it normal to separate families. Violence and terror are not OK. Immigrants need to know that their struggle is yours as well.‚Äù

You can watch Luna's powerful monologue below:

Title: 10 movies that wouldn't exist without the Sundance Directors Lab
Description:
Sundance has always been more than a film festival. As the indie mecca stares down a move away from Park City, there's the inclination to look backwards at the impact Robert Redford's brainchild has had on the industry at large over its long existence. This impact reaches far beyond the actual movies accepted into and screened at its festival, extending to those made by filmmakers nurtured at its various Labs‚Äîfilmmakers like Sinners‚Äò Ryan Coogler, whose Fruitvale Station got its start at the fest (and who stopped living at his parents' house thanks to a grant facilitated by the Institute). The development side of Sundance has kickstarted the careers of countless directors who've gone on to be household names, ranging from Quentin Tarantino and the Daniels to Paul Thomas Anderson and Chlo√© Zhao. As the 45th Directors Lab comes to a close, here are 10 projects that wouldn't exist without this important side of Sundance.

Ôªø

The first lab-supported film to be produced, after being developed at the first Directors Lab held in 1981, Gregory Nava's El Norte blends magical realism and the grounded stories of political refugees. A film that not only earned Nava and his co-writer Anna Thomas an Oscar nomination, but helped influence decades of U.S. immigration policy, El Norte focuses on people that Nava felt ‚Äúwere like shadows that people didn't see. They didn't see their heart and their soul.‚Äù A film filled with undocumented, Indigenous characters, El Norte remains viscerally relevant in addition to being bitingly satirical and remarkably shot in low light. Its early days at Sundance helped Nava achieve his vision. Speaking to the Los Angeles Times, he remembered that ‚ÄúWe worked with Sydney Pollack. We worked with Waldo Salt. One of the requests that I made to Sundance was that in order to do El Norte, we would have to bring professional actors together with nonactors. So they brought Ivan Passer, the great Czechoslovakian filmmaker who had done Intimate Lighting and who really knew how to work with nonactors.‚Äù

Ôªø

The poster boy for the indie wave represented by Sundance, Quentin Tarantino didn't just launch his debut gangster movie at the fest out of the blue. Rather, the ‚Äúanyone can make it‚Äù story of a video store obsessive had the springboard of Harvey Keitel, who liked the script and got things fast-tracked with his commitment. But Reservoir Dogs also had a more experienced Tarantino behind the camera thanks to the 1991 Directors Lab. There, he worked with established industry figures like Terry Gilliam, Stanley Donen, Volker Schl√∂ndorff, and Robert Estrin to figure out the look of the feature‚Äîto ‚Äúget out of his system‚Äù some overly energetic ideas that simply wouldn't do service to the script that made him famous, as Gilliam recalled.

Ôªø

Paul Thomas Anderson's first feature, originally titled Sydney after its gambler-mentor played by Philip Baker Hall, Hard Eight shot the directorial wunderkind into the spotlight when he was just 23. Sydney grew from Anderson's first scrappy short, Cigarettes & Coffee, which screened at Sundance and was similarly bolstered by the presence of Hall. That experience led to Anderson's invitation to the 1993 Directors Lab, the expansion of the short into a feature, and then‚Äîin a sequence of events John H. Richardson called ‚Äúalmost mythical, a parable about the necessity of real art‚Äù‚Äîthe repossessing of the film from financiers who almost ruined it. But they didn't ruin it; Anderson restored the vision he'd worked on at the Lab, got it into Cannes, and used the ensuing goodwill to get Boogie Nights off the ground.

Ôªø

Gina Prince-Bythewood worked in TV for years before making her film debut with Love & Basketball. After writing on South Central and directing an episode of CBS Schoolbreak Special, Prince-Bythewood took her personal sports-romance to Sundance's labs, where she connected with Spike Lee, who would produce the film with the same ethos he expected from his partners: total autonomy for the creative behind the camera. After a few years of work in and out of Directors and Screenwriters Labs, Love & Basketball premiered at Sundance in 2000. The indie classic didn't immediately translate into career success for its writer-director, but 25 years since its premiere, she's in the middle of a career resurgence, having pivoted to female-fronted action with The Old Guard and The Woman King.

Ôªø

Though Nicole Holofcener was born into the industry (and then further thrust into the film world through her stepfather Charles H. Joffe, who was Woody Allen's manager/producer), she didn't strike out on her own until more than a decade after working on films like A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy and Hannah And Her Sisters‚Äîand working at a video store. But after her five-minute short Angry made it to Sundance, she entered the Directors Lab the following year to workshop Walking And Talking, which would become her debut feature. Even then, it took over half a decade to get the thing made, wrangled by super producer Ted Hope and Holofcener's chance meeting with Catherine Keener at the gym. The simple film was a standout in a mid-'90s wave of chatty, neurotic comedies, and laid the groundwork for Holofcener's more complex future films.

Ôªø

There was a decent chance that Hedwig And The Angry Inch, Stephen Trask and John Cameron Mitchell's musical rebel yell from a genderqueer punk, might've just stayed a surprise, scrappy off-Broadway hit. Stage star Mitchell was well-equipped to reprise his role, but he also made the film adaptation his directorial debut though he had little experience behind the camera. That meant a few years of development work at the Labs, connecting Mitchell with collaborators like cinematographer Frank G. DeMarco and would-be directors like Forest Whitaker (imagine that take on the film for a second). Thanks to some of the team's behind-the-scenes connections, the film had distribution and financing before Mitchell was ready to shoot a thing, but it took a year of ramping up and learning before he and his team were able to replicate the DIY spirit of the show.

Ôªø

After getting her start doing collaborative DIY video projects in Portland's riot grrrl scene and various oddball performance pieces, Miranda July submitted her first feature script to the Screenwriters Lab and got rejected‚Ä¶twice. But the third time was the charm, which led to the Directors Lab where she'd spend three-and-a-half weeks working on her debut feature, Me And You And Everyone We Know, with creative advisors like Chuck & Buck director Miguel Arteta. But once July got her foot in the door, she took full advantage of the Institute's offerings, attending writing, directing, composing, and producing events as she was getting ready to make her film. Add in a few eccentric details befitting a July story‚Äîa Japanese broadcaster ended up helping keep the film's financing afloat before IFC came aboard‚Äîand you have a strange underdog story worthy of the ‚Äú))<>((‚Äù emoticon.

Ôªø

Speaking of bodily functions represented in ridiculous ways, Swiss Army Man took filmmakers Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert from the viral music video circuit to the feature film world. Just a few years later, they'd all but sweep the Oscars with Everything Everywhere All At Once. But the road to their farting corpse comedy (starring Paul Dano and Daniel Radcliffe) was long. The same year the Daniels were winning awards for their ‚ÄúTurn Down For What‚Äù video, they had attended the Sundance writing lab, where Quentin Tarantino tried to get them to put the Gilligan's Island theme into the film. They didn't follow his advice (or continue on with Beck Bennett, who played the Daniel Radcliffe corpse role at the Labs), but the work at Sundance helped the film make its polarizing debut at the fest just a few years later. Or, to put it in Scheinert's words, ‚ÄúThank God [Robert Redford] bought that shitty land.‚Äù

Ôªø

It's not like Boots Riley needed Sundance to find success as an artist. The rapper-turned-filmmaker has been making hits with The Coup since the early '90s (no other director on this list is featured in a music video with E-40 and 2Pac) but his political, satirical writing finally made it to the big screen in Sorry To Bother You, the stylish spectacle where LaKeith Stanfield puts on his ‚Äúwhite voice‚Äù as a telemarketer. Originally, the script simply served as the inspiration for The Coup's sixth album, and was later published in McSweeney's. But that was enough to get him into the Sundance pipeline, which hooked him up with a creative team (and mentors like David Gordon Green, Guillermo del Toro, and Joan Tewkesbury, as well as advisors like Chiwetel Ejiofor and Bradford Young) that helped the former film school student make his feature debut. 

ÔªøÔªø

One of the strongest debuts of the last few years, Charlotte Wells' Aftersun not only helped launch its filmmaker into the arthouse conversation, but jettisoned star Paul Mescal into the spotlight. Wells, an NYU graduate who began exploring similar themes in her first short film Tuesday, worked at industry service provider Digital Orchard and then as a producer before her artistic trajectory changed. After her shorts Laps and Blue Christmas got into Sundance, she'd made the contacts necessary to get Aftersun moving, but the COVID pandemic derailed things. This freed her up to go through a virtual version of the Directors Lab in 2020, which she cites as transformative to the film. While she got ‚Äúlots of practical advice about directing and prep,‚Äù Wells also ran into feedback she disagreed with around the tension (or lack thereof) between the central father-daughter duo. ‚ÄúSometimes when you hear something you disagree with,‚Äù she told Deadline, ‚Äúit clarifies your own position.‚Äù So she went her own way, and found herself racking up the awards for her trouble.

GET A.V.CLUB RIGHT IN YOUR INBOX

Title: 'Bridgerton' Star Proudly Walks 'F1' Premiere Red Carpet Despite Being Cut From Film [PHOTOS]
Description:
Giving everyone a masterclass in grace, Simone Ashley proudly stepped out to celebrate ‚ÄúF1: The Movie‚Äù on Monday (June 23). Simone attended the European premiere in London despite her role being cut from the final version of the film. 

The 30-year-old actress walked the red carpet solo at Cineworld Leicester Square, stunning in a gold Balmain gown. Simone's move depicts a graceful show of support for the project and her castmates.

Ashley had previously filmed scenes for F1, but does not have any speaking lines in the finished movie. 

Director Joseph Kosinski recently explained the change, telling People: ‚ÄúIt happens on every film, where you have to shoot more than you can use. There were two or three storylines that ultimately didn't make it into the final cut. But Simone, she's an incredible talent, incredible actress, incredible singer, and I would love to work with her again.‚Äù

Ashley had been seen on set and was also photographed at a Miami promotional event for F1, appearing with co-star Kerry Condon and producer Jerry Bruckheimer.

The ‚ÄúBridgerton‚Äù star doesn't believe in holding grudges. Speaking to ELLE earlier this month, Ashley said: ‚ÄúI have a very small part, but I'm grateful to be in that movie‚Ä¶ I got to experience many Grand Prix. I don't think I'll ever do anything like that again.‚Äù

Director Kosinski, 51, also told Entertainment Tonight that he informed Ashley that her scenes would not appear in the final cut, and praised her professionalism and talent.

Ashley previously told Who What Wear that her role in F1 had been in the works long before her breakout on ‚ÄúBridgerton‚Äù. 

She said, ‚ÄúI met for this movie, I think, before Bridgerton even came out. It's been a long time, and you know, it's Damson and Brad's movie. I'm just so grateful that I can be part of it.‚Äù

Though her scenes didn't make it to the screen, Simone Ashley's grace and support at the London premiere spoke volumes. She proved why she remains one of the industry's most beloved rising stars. 

Brad Pitt leads ‚ÄúF1: The Movie‚Äù as a retired Formula One driver making a comeback with a fictional team. 

The film, written by Ehren Kruger and produced in collaboration with real F1 stars including Lewis Hamilton, also features Damson Idris, Tobias Menzies, Kim Bodnia, Javier Bardem, Shea Whigham, and more.

‚ÄúF1: The Movie‚Äù opens in theaters nationwide on June 27.

Title: HGTV's Ben Napier Reveals ‚ÄòAbsolute Scariest Thing' About Being a New Parent
Description:
HGTV ‚ÄúHome Town‚Äù star Ben Napier is a loving father to two girls, but he admits he experienced one scary part of parenthood early on. Find out why Napier called it the ‚Äúabsolute scariest thing.‚Äù

A post shared by Ben Napier | Scotsman Co. (@scotsman.co)

In a June 2025 interview with Country Living, Napier shared some words of wisdom from his experience as a dad.

‚ÄúI have two warnings and one piece of advice for first-time parents, things that were never told to me,‚Äù he explained, including what he calls the ‚Äúscariest thing.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy first warning is ‚Äî and I may sound like an idiot for saying it ‚Äî the first night home from the hospital is the absolute scariest thing you will go through,‚Äù Napier said. ‚ÄúWe had been in the hospital for two or three days, the baby had spent both nights in the nursery at the hospital ‚Äî and it was great.‚Äù

He continued, ‚ÄúThen we came home that first night, and she cried all night. I was trying to let Erin sleep, sitting on the couch holding Helen, and as long as I kept moving, she wouldn't cry.‚Äù

Napier also admitted he didn't know too much about women's hormones. ‚ÄúYour wife has nine months of the craziest hormonal swings ever while she's pregnant ‚Äî but then in my mind, it was like, ‚ÄòAlright, baby's here, hormone changes are over!' And that's not how it works.‚Äù

He shared, ‚ÄúI was unprepared for the next three to six months of hormonal changes that were going on. So if you're a boy who grew up in a house full of boys, just know: That's coming.‚Äù

A post shared by Shades of Light (@shadesoflight)

As for his advice, Napier offered some solid tips about giving yourself grace when you have a baby.

‚ÄúThen the advice is to just be gentle with each other,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEveryone ‚Äî including the baby ‚Äî is going to be out of whack.‚Äù

The HGTV star continued, ‚ÄúBe gentle with everyone. Yourself too. You're tired, and they're tired, and maybe you're hungry, and you're scared.‚Äù

Napier added, ‚ÄúBut it's going to be okay. Everything is going to be all right.‚Äù

He also advised not to ‚Äúread into what the world is telling you about, Oh, this is how you should raise your baby.‚Äù Napier explained, ‚ÄúEvery baby is different and every family is different, and what works for yours may not work for theirs.‚Äù

Title: How Dakota Johnson Is Embracing Life After Chris Martin Split
Description:
Dakota Johnson is embracing a new chapter. She is moving forward with strength and purpose just weeks after her split from longtime partner Chris Martin.

A source close to the ‚ÄòMaterialists' actor spoke to People and said, ‚ÄúDakota's doing well. The split wasn't exactly a shock,‚Äù. The insider added that Johnson, 35, and the Coldplay frontman, 48, ‚Äúhad the same issues for a while.‚Äù

Multiple sources confirmed to People on June 4 that Johnson and Martin had ended their nearly eight-year relationship. The couple was first linked in 2017 and were last photographed together in Malibu on May 16.

A post shared by üáπüá∑ Coldplay T√ºrkiye | coldplayturkeypage (@coldplayturkeypage)

About three months earlier, a source told People the couple had been engaged ‚Äúfor years.‚Äù 

The insider added that they were ‚Äúin no rush to get married‚Äù after first sparking engagement rumors in 2020.

A post shared by curators of pop culture (@deuxmoi)

The couple had faced breakup rumors in August 2024. Later, Johnson's rep shut down at the time. One insider had noted: ‚ÄúThey've had issues and taken breaks in the past, but things are great now. They both love their careers. They are balancing things the best they can.‚Äù

‚ÄúDakota wants to live her life very intentionally ‚Äî she doesn't want to have any regrets,‚Äù the source told People in a report published on June 23rd. 

After years of balancing a busy career with a high-profile relationship, Johnson is now focusing on what truly matters to her. 

‚ÄúShe loves all her creative projects and is excited about her career. She believes there is more to life than work, though. She wants a meaningful life on all levels,‚Äù the insider adds.

Johnson is currently starring in ‚ÄúMaterialists‚Äù, which premiered in theaters on June 13. 

Her next film, ‚ÄúSplitsville‚Äù, is set to premiere on Aug. 22. Watch the trailer here:

Martin, meanwhile, was spotted out in New York City on June 16 with his son, Moses, 19. The singer also shares daughter Apple, 21, with ex-wife Gwyneth Paltrow.

Johnson had previously opened up about her bond with Martin's children in a March 2024 Bustle interview. ‚ÄúI love those kids like my life depends on it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWith all my heart.‚Äù

She also shared her love of watching Martin perform: ‚ÄúI could watch him every day. I don't know how to explain it. ‚Ä¶ I'm watching my most favorite being do his most favorite thing.‚Äù

Martin will resume touring with Coldplay in Toronto on July 7, with shows across North America and England through Sept. 8.

A post shared by Coldplay (@coldplay)

Fans, however, believe that the breakup may have had an emotional impact on Martin.

 In a June 19 post on X (formerly Twitter), PopTingz shared a clip of Martin performing Sparks, noting he got emotional and softly added ‚Äúyes I will‚Äù after singing ‚ÄúI won't let you down.

While the breakup may have saddened fans of one of Hollywood's favorite couples, Dakota Johnson appears to be entering a new chapter.

Title: Adam Levine Says He's Used to ‚ÄòNot Fitting In' Anywhere
Description:
Maroon 5 frontman and ‚ÄúThe Voice‚Äù coach Adam Levine has sold millions of records around the world, but the Grammy winner still doesn't feel like he's found his niche ‚Äî and that's quite alright with him. 

On June 23, 2025, the group announced its first new album in four years, ‚ÄúLove is Like,‚Äù will be released in August, supported by a U.S. tour. 

In an interview with Lisa Thomas of iHeartRadio's KIIS-FM on June 17, Levine said the band is getting back to ‚Äúwhat we used to do, which is like, not pay attention to anything at all‚Äù in terms of genres or trends. While that's been problematic at times for record executives since Maroon 5 broke onto the scene in 2002, Levine said he's most comfortable and successful when he's ‚Äúnot fitting in.‚Äù

During his interview with Thomas, Levine said the new record ‚Äúwas, like, a very isolated album.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe live in Santa Barbara now,‚Äù Levine said of his wife Behati Prinsloo and their three children. ‚ÄúAnd I was in a room with very few people and producing the music kind of organically,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt's about as organic as it gets right so like it doesn't follow any trends, really, I don't think.‚Äù 

‚ÄúBecause that's kind of how we stuck out in the beginning when we first started our career,‚Äù Levine recalled. ‚ÄúLike I don't think we fit in anywhere. I think that was, in fact, like one of the biggest concerns for the record labels that we were trying to sign to, was like, ‚ÄòOh well, these guys fit in ‚Ä¶ they're like pop group but they're a band but they're this.'‚Äù

‚ÄúSo, not fitting in is kind of what I'm most comfortable with,‚Äù Levine said. ‚ÄúAnd I think now we're kind of starting to not fit in again, which is great.‚Äù

Levine was one of the original coaches on ‚ÄúThe Voice,‚Äù launching the show in 2011 with Blake Shelton, Christina Aguilera, and CeLo Green. After 16 seasons, he shocked fans when he abruptly left the show in 2019, telling media outlets including ‚ÄúThe Ellen DeGeneres Show‚Äù that he wanted to spend more time with his family.

He announced his return to the series in June 2024, just before filming started on season 27 with Michael Bubl√©, John Legend, and first-time coach Kelsea Ballerini. The season wrapped in May 2025, with Team Bubl√©'s Adam David winning. 

Soon after the show wrapped, reports surfaced that Levine didn't love being back on the show as much as he expected, missing his sarcastic banter with Shelton. It's already confirmed that he won't return for season 28, which will air in the fall, but with an upcoming tour, it's highly unlikely that Levine would be able to join season 29 either.

Title: Best Hallmark Blooper Ever? New Clip Has Fans in Stitches After Actor ‚ÄòLet One Rip'
Description:
With an archive of more than a thousand original movies produced over the last 15 years, Hallmark Channel and its stars have shared plenty of cute and funny bloopers with fans. But the outtake that Ashley Williams posted on June 22, 2025, in honor of Paul Campbell's birthday may very well take the cake as the best Hallmark blooper ever.

Williams waited over a year to share what happened as they filmed the final scene of ‚ÄúFalling Together‚Äù in the spring of 2024. During what was meant to be a sweet, romantic moment, Williams wrote in the caption, ‚Äúa background actor‚Ä¶ let one rip RIGHT by where Paul and I were about to kiss.‚Äù 

‚ÄúIt's the blooperiest of bloopers and it makes me cry laughing to this day,‚Äù she wrote, and then made matters even funnier with a smattering of puns, joking, ‚ÄúPaul, you are the wind beneath my wings. The air in my tires. You blow me away. Happy birthday, partner.‚Äù

A post shared by Ashley Williams (@ashleywilliamsandcompany)

Williams added narrative text over the video to ensure fans could tell exactly when the flatulence in question occurred. In a scene designed to look like one of the Alzheimer's Association's annual fundraising walks, Campbell could be heard delivering his line to Williams. 

Over the video, she pointed out in text, ‚ÄúHere's the fart. You really gotta listen‚Ä¶We both CLEARLY hear it. But the camera is still rolling so we can't react.‚Äù

Trying to stifle their laughter, Williams says through gritted teeth, ‚ÄúWe have to kiss.‚Äù After smooching, she whispers and wheezily giggles, ‚ÄúDid you hear that?‚Äù and Campbell kisses her again just to disguise their laughter. 

As the camera pans out, she writes over the video, ‚ÄúWe cut. I collapse on Paul.‚Äù 

Many fans said they were in tears over the blooper video, flooding Williams' post with comments, including one who wrote, ‚ÄúI'm crying from laughter watching this! ü§£‚Äù and another who called it ‚Äúthe best thing ever üòÇ‚Äù

One fan commented, ‚ÄúI laughed so hard and laughed even harder hearing you laugh üòÇ‚Äù

Someone else admitted, ‚Äúyou are a hoot Ashley Williams, you made me laugh so hard, I about peed myself üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ‚Äù

‚ÄúI have no idea how you kept your composure so well,‚Äù someone else wrote. ‚ÄúI died laughing immediatly!!! üòÇü§£‚Äù

A post shared by Erin Krakow (@erinkrakow)

Williams has every right to toot her own horn about the hilarious blooper from ‚ÄúFalling Together,‚Äù which premiered on Hallmark Channel in September. But believe it or not, it's not the only gas-induced outtake in the Hallmark archives. In 2023, a gassy horse named Noodles caused a bit of a stir during the filming of ‚ÄúWhen Calls The Heart‚Äù season 10. 

Plenty of other mishaps have been responsible for laugh-out-loud bloopers on the sets of Hallmark movies and series over the years, with stars getting tongue-tied or tripped up over what's happening on-set. 

One classic, seen above, is from the 2021 Tyler Hynes and Erin Krakow rom-com ‚ÄúIt Was Always You,‚Äù in which he timed his invitation to dance just-right each time she took a swig of champagne, causing her to bust out laughing. 

In early June, Hallmark provided a montage of funny outtakes to ‚ÄúEntertainment Tonight‚Äù of Williams and Alison Sweeney filming their ‚ÄúTo Barcelona‚Äù movies, including shots of Williams spilling Italian food on herself. 

In 2021, Williams (are you noticing a theme here?) was featured in another adorable blooper reel with her sister, Kimberly Williams-Paisley, to promote their ‚ÄúSister Swap‚Äù movies.

Title: Robert Downey Jr. Says Pedro Pascal's Rise to Fame ‚ÄòReaffirms My Faith in Our Industry'
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Robert Downey Jr. is singing Pedro Pascal‚Äòs praises. Both actors are appearing in the next Phase of the MCU, with Pascal leading ‚ÄúThe Fantastic Four: First Steps‚Äù as Reed Richards AKA Mr. Fantastic and Downey as Victor Von Doom AKA Doctor Doom for ‚ÄúAvengers: Doomsday.‚Äù Will they first square off in ‚ÄúFirst Steps‚Äù? Unclear. However, that didn't stop Downey from pointing to how Pascal is an inspiration for Hollywood as a whole.

‚ÄúPascal's slow trajectory to becoming a household name who is on a wildly hot streak kind of reaffirms my faith in our industry,‚Äù Downey told Vanity Fair. And it's true: Pascal really is everywhere. In addition to starring in ‚ÄúThe Fantastic Four,‚Äù the actor appears in ‚ÄúThe Last of Us,‚Äù ‚ÄúMaterialists,‚Äù ‚ÄúEddington,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Mandalorian.‚Äù 

 








Related Stories Some of the Best Sound Design This Year Is in a Documentary About Marlee Matlin Cannes 2025 Films Sold So Far: Janus Films Acquires Ukrainian Drama ‚ÄòTwo Prosecutors' 

And Pascal is also a newfound staple at Downey's own home, too. Pascal teased to VF that he (and presumably, his fellow ‚ÄúFantastic Four‚Äù co-stars Vanessa Kirby, Ebon Moss-Bachrach, and Joseph Quinn) has been part of the ‚Äú‚ÄòAvengers' cast ‚Äòhomework' day,‚Äù hosted by Downey, as VF reported. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






Pascal said, ‚ÄúI don't know, I don't know,‚Äù when asked if he too was an Avenger, but it's evident that Downey at least is circling the wagons for the franchise given his return to the MCU. Downey was announced in 2024 as Doctor Doom after playing Iron Man for more than a decade. 

Pascal told VF that he was nervous about joining the acclaimed MCU franchise alongside so many icons‚Ä¶and fan opinions. Yet Downey eased the way for Pascal. 

‚ÄúI'm more aware of disgruntlement around my casting than anything I've ever done. ‚ÄòHe's too old. He's not right. He needs to shave,'‚Äù Pascal said, adding that Downey made him feel comfortable about his ‚ÄúFantastic Four‚Äù role. ‚ÄúHe's just so immediately generous and inviting that you feel like you can be afraid, you can be hungry, you can be ambivalent.‚Äù 

And Downey isn't the only MCU member who adores Pascal: ‚ÄúThe Fantastic Four‚Äù star Vanessa Kirby, who plays Pascal's onscreen wife, said that Pascal has an ‚Äúimmense vulnerability‚Äù as an actor. ‚ÄúHe doesn't have much armor, so he shows himself to you straight away,‚Äù she said of his inspirational acting techniques, ‚Äúand you trust that person because he's revealing himself to you in this very brave way.‚Äù 

Director Spike Jonze (who is unaffiliated with Marvel‚Ä¶.as of now), helmed an Apple ad with Pascal and summarized the actor's appeal: ‚ÄúI think that he's what we want in masculinity.‚Äù And given Pascal's meteoric rise to fame, that proves to be a fact.
